etymology.description: phonetic 爿 + semantic 肉 (‘meat’) + semantic 寸 (‘hand’) — offering meat as tribute; ⺼ is on its side (resembles 夕), and 爿 may also suggest a cutting board/altar.
etymology.interpretation: A hand presenting meat suggests offering or bringing something forward, which underlies senses like ‘to lead/bring’ and later ‘will’. 爿 supplies the sound and can also evoke the board or altar on which the meat is set.
etymology.simplification: 将 streamlines 將 by keeping the phonetic 爿 as its left-side form 丬, reducing ⺼ to 夕, and dropping 寸, preserving pronunciation cues while cutting strokes.

examples.chinese: 我将去北京(我將去北京)。
他将书放在桌上(他將書放在桌上)。
examples.pinyin: Tā jiāng shū fàng zài zhuō shàng.
examples.english: He put the book on the table.
